    Larchmonter445 • a day ago

    This article is comprehensive, but lacks one major component—Russia. Russia has skin in the game of Asia. It has its disputed regions with Japan, it has a stake in controlling the DPRK and the nuclear threat from North Korea. It has a new very strategic economic relationship with China.

    How do you write a major review of the last several years of the state of the East China and South China Sea disputes and leave Russia out?

            Lucilius Larchmonter445 • a day ago

            It does leave out Russia, but almost all of the disputes with China are occurring far to the southeast. While Russia does have a new economic agreement with China, I suspect that may a temporary expedient to secure one front while Putin strives to rebuild the old Soviet empire in the west. In the long run, Russia is demographically fading, while China is hungry for more land and resources - all tantalizingly available north of the Amur.

                Larchmonter445 Lucilius • a day ago

                Disagree with several of your comments.
                Russia is not rebuilding any Soviet empire. They are responding to the containment via NATO encroaching and US destabilizing via proxy Ukraine. Crimea is merely a return of what was always Russian, and Ukraine disintegration is natural due to corruption and its proxy status against Russia. You reap what you sow, and the Hegemon is reaping reaction to its attempts to destroy the Russian Federation.

                China may be hungry for resources, but it's maritime reach is based on historical realities. The U.S. is desperate to maintain its naval hegemony, and China is nullifying that with its carrier-killer missile threat. A new Maritime Silk Road and a proposed canal through Thailand would eliminate the Straits of Malacca as a choke point the U.S. controls. Who is trying to limit who where? Its the US trying to stop China from being a true blue water naval power. The U.S. using an imperialistic Japan to torment China, Taiwan and South Korea in the Yellow Sea and East China Sea.

                The 20th Century realities are gone. China and Russia will build a Eurasian market of over 3.5 billion people from the Far East and South Asia (India) to Russia and East Europe through Central Asia. This coming realty is what reduces the West and its corrupt EU, maniacal Nato, and collapsing American governmental tyranny to secondary position if they don't change from Hegemon to a multi-polar player.

                Dig into the facts of the SCO, the New Silk Road, the Maritime Silk Road and look at the militarism of Abe's Japan and the use of the Philippines as proxy for the US.

                China merely is the new bank for all emerging and most developing nations. A role once filled by a financially sound U.S. Now, the U.S. can only spread chaos and attempt de-stabilization to hold onto power. It's run as an empire is coming to an end. It may take ten more years, but debt will be the victor over the tyrant. The Liberals inherited the world and have destroyed it with their ideologies and wars.

                Russia and China signed strategic economic and technological agreements far beyond the big gas deal. Now they are working on space, jumbo airliner, weapons, agriculture, rail, home construction, ports, bridges, pipelines, education, IT security, oil and gas and fresh water projects, food, currency, banking and finance (substitute for SWIFT and use of the Chinese credit card system). The Far East and Siberia, and Crimea and East Ukraine (now Novorossiya) are all areas of integration of Chinese and Russian development, as well as Northeast China (Heliongjiang Province) opening up to Russia projects.

                Even India is getting Chinese investment for its infrastructure projects. If India wasn't so corrupt, they would have many more Chinese built ports and highways. The Chinese are going to modernize the India rail system.

                The U.S. maybe thinks it can send Tweets and try to start some more color revolutions, but it has very little to offer to any but the most subservient nations. It is bringing down all its allies with debt and draconian Trade agreements. Look into TTIP and TTP and see how it colonizes any nation that joins. Pure hegemony in exchange for a nuclear umbrella and debt.

                    But thanks for the rant - it made me laugh.

                            Matthew Spira PW • a day ago

                            I did get a laugh at the dig at India's (96/177 in the 2013 Corruption Perceptions Index) level of corruption, when corruption is just as endemic in both China (80/177) and especially Russia (127/177).

                            (By comparison, the United States' ranking is 19/177.)

                            And much of the economic growth in China has been fueled by the "shadow banking" system, which is functionally the equivalent of a house of cards built on quicksand.
                            There are other signifiicant challenges to the vision of economic integration outlined above, but I can't be bothered to write a W.O.T. at the moment.

                                                                                                                                  • +
                                                                                                                                  Ubik marathag • 2 hours ago
                                                                                                                                  You realize that Mexico attacked US forces first, right?

                                                                                                                                  I'm assuming you're referring to the Thornton Affair? That may have provided a sufficient casus belli for Polk (along with Mexico's rejection of John Slidell's offer to forgive $3 million in debt for damages incurred during their war of independence in addition to paying $25-$30 million for Alta California and Santa Fe de Nuevo México), but it's virtually impossible to construe the Americans as anything other than the aggressors.

                                                                                                                                  To do so would ignore America's repeated violations of Mexican sovereignty, such as John C. Frémont's military expedition into California in the winter of 1845-46, which culminated in him building a fort and raising the American flag at said fort. Afterwards, he went on to assist the Bear Flag Revolt. It also ignores American military intervention in the border dispute between Mexico and the Republic of Texas, as Polk sent 3,500 troops under Zachary Taylor in July 1845 to the Nueces River and authorized him to seize the disputed land by force if necessary.

                                                                                                                                          Ubik marathag • 34 minutes ago
                                                                                                                                          In those ' violations of Mexican sovereignty ' how many Mexican Soldiers were killed?

                                                                                                                                          It's irrelevant. America sent an armed expedition, built a fort and claimed it as their own on sovereign Mexican soil, then went on to provide direct military support to rebels. Taylor's expeditionary force on the Nueces Strip arrived months prior to Texas's annexation, while it was still being voted on in both Texas and the US. The US was intervening in what was a border dispute between two ostensibly sovereign nations.

                                                                                                                                          Mexico had a tradition of border violations, see the Dawson Massacre, since they never recognized Texas independence or them joining the USA.

                                                                                                                                          Santa Anna signed the Treaties of Velasco without authorization from the Mexican government; he was also under coercion as he was imprisoned, thus the treaties had no legal standing. While Mexico was generally an unstable mess during this time, I don't believe any of the various governments ever ratified them or recognized them as legitimate. Perhaps most importantly, Santa Anna's treaties would not have been considered legitimate under the Mexican constitution, as he did not have the authority to sign such documents.

                                                                                                                                        GeorgeA Bulos Qoqish • 4 hours ago

                                                                                                                                        You are correct. I am well aware of the US territorial conquests in the 19th and very early 20th centuries. I've read a number of good books on the subjects. Those events were also a long time ago when international norms were different. Since that age of imperialism, the world catastrophe of the mid 20th century has reshaped the world order to a better place. China is flouting this order now, not 100 years ago. Why does that make it OK for China to behave like the US or Japan behaved 100 years ago, when the history is clear that acting in such a way only leads to destruction and chaos? You cannot condemn the US for its history, and then turn around and use that history to excuse Chinese behavior in the present. THAT is classic propaganda doublethink.

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                Hanfeizi UncleStu • 7 hours ago

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                Of course, there's one crucial difference between the Soviet Union's millitary buildup and China's- Deng pegged the military buildup to GDP, insisting that the military's share could never rise about 4% on his watch (unlike the Soviet Union, whose military took roughly 25-35% at it's peak).

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                It never has, but back when 4% meant 4% of squat, it wasn't much of a threat.                                                                                                                                                                                                                                     • −
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                    • +
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                    NicolasBourbaki • a day ago

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                    This is highly inaccurate and biased. Unlike Russia, China has for a very long time claimed much of these areas. Russia voluntarily gave up Crimea in the 70s but has unilaterally reclaimed it. These areas that China and its neighbors claim are considered disputed territory within international law unlike Crimea which has been Ukrainian autonomous region for more than 40 years.

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                    Second, some historical context. China has more land borders with other countries than any country in the world and because of that fact one of the most territorial disputes historically. It has resolved almost all of them (except with India) peacefully through negotiation. That is unprecedented as most territorial disputes are resolved militarily.

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                    China's so called aggression in the S. China seas today is actually a tit for tat strategy when their negotiation offers have been rebuffed and they have come under aggressive behavior from its neighbors (such as when Japan allowed the government to buy a disputed island or Vietnam's aggressive naval actions). Remember, Japan didn't even consider the Islands China also claims to be disputed territory until last year. There was and probably still is no hope of negotiation.

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                    Third, according to a study by the political scientist Joshua Goldstein, China is the most peaceful of all major military powers in the last 40 years.

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                    http://www.foreignpolicy.com/a...

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                    So the odds of war, though bigger than most people imagine in these territorial disputes, may not necessarily be due to Chinese aggression as this and almost all other articles in the western press suggest.
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                      see more

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        Archdukechocula NicolasBourbaki • a day ago

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        You do realize that talking about negotiations to resolve a conflict and then describing the conflict as "peaceful" would mean that you are describing Vietnam and the Korean War as "peaceful resolved conflicts" right?                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                         Archdukechocula NicolasBourbaki • a day ago

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        Negotiation:
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        noun

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        1. mutual discussion and arrangement of the terms of a transaction or agreement: "the negotiation of a treaty."

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        You know, like exactly what happened in the First Armistice at Compiègne. If you would care to offer some wholly unique, not commonly accepted definition of negotiation that magically includes the resolution to the Korean War and not WW1, by all means offer it up. Until then, I'm afraid it appears you are the one that has no idea what they are talking about.

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        It's also the opinion of every country in the world. The Tibetans didn't get an explicit consent to be a part of China but neither did the people of every state in the US get a choice whether their state is to be part of the US. That's a red herring.

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                            Yes, your argument is in fact a red herring. What you are implying is that what, every generation should have a vote on what country they want to be part of? If that were to take place, the US would still very likely have 50 states. China would be TIbetless.

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        David Myra Esoteric • 13 hours ago

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        You are absolutely incorrect; unlike Xinjiang or Inner Mongolia, which have been flooded with Han colonists over the last two centuries until they are, respectively, 45% and 85% Han, Tibet remains well over 80% ethnically Tibetan. Even leaving aside religious issues, those Tibetans constitute an abused majority with little more political and economic power than Africans had under Apartheid. Direct racism isn't as prevalent, but the sheer prevalence of the security state and the automatic suspicion it exercises towards non-Han people in Tibet put the worst excesses of Stop-and-Frisk to shame.

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        Put it to a vote and I guarantee they'd leave in a heartbeat, but Beijing understandably cannot consider the possibility as the Tibetan Plateau contains the headwaters for the river systems which supply three-quarters of a billion people with water and food. What it would do, if it was even vaguely reasonable on the issue, is try to treat the locals well enough that they wouldn't feel the need to leave, just as it should be doing in Xinjiang, which it similarly *must* control in order to secure overland access to energy resources from Central Asia and Russia.

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                            Come on of course any minority faces bigotry, which is part of the reason China's affirmative action program reaches further than that of the US. Of course the struggle against racism isn't over but it's a continual process. BTW. Tibetan people live all over China not just in Tibet or historic areas where they used to live.

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                            Many people of Tibetan race, for example, migrate to Shanghai and other major cities without an issue. They join the Communist party and have regular jobs, live in suburbs like everyone else.

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                It would be a moot point, anyway. A "free" Tibet, like a "free" Xinjiang, would be a client state of China. All the significant logstical links and markets are there, and the Han control all the businesses. They might have a freer government, like Mongolia, but that's about it- Mongolia is also pretty much a wholly-owned subsidiary of China, Inc. (or at least a three-quarters owned subsidiary).

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                    Look I don't give a damn if they become independent but I just think a lot of pro-West commentators use 'free Tibet' as an excuse to screw with countries that aren't soft colonies of the US.

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                    The vast majority of people in China, regardless of area, honestly don't give a damn.                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                             First of all Tibet was part of the former Mongolian and Manchurian empires, which also colonized central China. The issue is that I think they consented to be part of Mongolia and Manchuria, and those cultures were historically very different from mainstream Chinese culture, but more similar to Tibet.

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                            When the socialist revolution happened it spread to many Asian countries. If Tibet had become independent, it may have become Soviet like Mongolia. Actually, one issue with Tibet was that the US's CIA went there in the 1950s to get them to break from socialism.

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                            A lot of the public opinion you hear about free Tibet etc. comes from people living in Nepal and India.                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                               NicolasBourbaki Tyler McGinty • a day ago

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                              There is no "conflict" between China and Tibet. Tibet is a part of China. You may not like that fact but the world doesn't revolve aorund your stupid opinions. You see, there is a thing called international law. There is no country that has denied that Tibet is a part of China. Even the Dalai Lama claims that it is a part of China. But white people like you love to speak on behalf of others.

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                              http://www.smh.com.au/news/Wor...

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                              "Tibet is a part of the People's Republic of China. It is an autonomous region of the People's Republic of China. Tibetan culture and Buddhism are part of Chinese culture."

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                  There isn't a dispute, because there's no such thing as Tibet, at least as far as the nation-state system is concerned. It would be like saying "the dispute between the US and the Lakota Nation"; the Lakota may argue that they're a conquered people whose land was taken from them, but there was never a Lakota nation-state as such that was recognized by the world. Tibet? Same.

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                            Myra Esoteric Hanfeizi • a day ago

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                            There was a Tibetan state before they joined the Mongolian and later Manchurian metastates. It was recognized by many countries in Asia. There are also people of Tibetan heritage living in various parts of China.

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                            But a lot of areas that have a problem with the Chinese government have problems with what they perceive as big-government policies, such as traditional Chinese laicization vs. their attitude regarding church and state.

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                            BTW. Check out this series on the history of socialism in Tibet. Actually many people supported the revolution originally.
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                            http://kasamaproject.org/histo...
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                              see more

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                Hanfeizi Myra Esoteric • a day ago

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                It was a kingdom; not a state in the modern, westphalian-system sense. Their lack of a sense of statehood went to the point that when offered recognition by the United Nations in the late 1940s, they rejected it, insisting that they were part of China. This was the way the situation stood until it became clear to the Dalai Lama's clique in the late 50s that they wouldn't have the autonomy that they expected and had enjoyed under previous regimes and dynasties... at which point they began to retroactively claim statehood. A decade and a half too late. (Note that the ROC government on Taiwan has never rescinded their claim to Tibet or Xinjiang either- or Outer Mongolia for that matter, which is a recognized, independent state.)

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                It becomes increasingly evident when you look at what the Tibetan Government in Exile claims as Tibet, which includes a lot more than the Xizang rump-province; it includes all of Qinghai, which is less than a third Tibetan to begin with, and has historically had large populations of Hui, Han, and other minorities. The Dalai Lama himself was born in Gansu province, which has been recognized as part of the Chinese core going back for centuries, but contains many Tibetan villages.

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                The whole idea of a Tibetan "state" simply doesn't make sense when superimposed on the ethnic complexities of central Asia. Same as the various manufactured "states" of the Middle East.
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                  see more
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                • 4

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                    Myra Esoteric Hanfeizi • a day ago

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                    Honestly according to the Westphalian nation-state concept, many non-Western societies were not 'states' until quite recently. But they were countries, with governments, and with an idea of being a country.

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                    Now I'm not pro-free Tibet. but Tibet definitely had its own form of governance and was a diverse place historically.
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                      see more
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                    • 0

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        • +
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        Hanfeizi Myra Esoteric • a day ago

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        Agreed. There's just so much misinformation that makes it sound like there was this "happy Shangri-la kingdom of Tibet" that was peacefully minding it's own business in Buddhist harmony when the big, bad Chinese communists invaded. Um, no. There was a patchwork of ethnic Tibetan kingdoms and communities that had been part of the Qing empire along with many other central and Southeast Asian tribes. After the fall of the Qing, they meandered their own way, sometimes under various foreign (Indian, Soviet, Chinese) influences, but remained part of the new Chinese Republic for all nominal purposes, and never really rejected it's position as Chinese territory- until it became clear that China wanted to run it as a Chinese territory, and not as a Tibetan-administered tributary sending tax revenues to Beijing in exchange for military protection. Which reminds me of another territory that's in the news a lot right now, but that's another story...
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                          see more
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        • 4

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        They have as legitimate a claim as anyone else.

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        In the eyes of international law, the Qing dynasty was the legitimate claimant to Tibet. The Republic of China was the successor state of the Qing Empire, and still claims ownership of Tibet. In the 1970s and 80s, international bodies gradually recognized the PRC as having replaced the ROC as successor state.

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                              albertocane Roger Thornhill • 13 hours ago

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                              Much of the blood you are talking was spilled by native Crimean Tartars... Countless thousands were murdered by the Red Terror in 1920. Countless thousands more died of starvation in the famine of 1921/22, when the Soviets confiscated all their grain. Tens of thousands more were murdered in the terror of 1929 in the Crimea. Then even more during the purges of 1937/38. Then the entire population of Tartars was deported to Siberia in 1944 for collaborating with the Germans (yes..the Tartars found them easier to get along with than the Soviets), killing countless thousands more. They eventually returned to the Crimea but in numbers far less than a few generations earlier.

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                              You are wrong about Khrushchev being a Ukrainian. Most school children know he was born in Kalinovka, Russia, which is near Kursk. He was 100% Russian. He was the Soviet Commissar to the Ukraine however. Stalin wanted another Russian keeping them under his heal. I am assuming you are just making up facts to support him making the Crimea part of the Ukraine. He did so primarily because all land links to the peninsula from the mainland went through the Ukraine.

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                              Besides that, you are right. After Russia defeated the Turks, and started eliminating the native tartars, they did achieve a majority of Russians there.

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                              Nobody except you and other Russians feel that justifies them to invade and confiscate part of a sovereign nation however.

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                              What a bunch of rubbish. Long claimed ? The Philippines has given dozens of examples of those islands never being claimed. The only major survey done of them by a chinese dynasty was done by Kublai Khan, a mongol who at the time had had conquered Korea, was invading Vietnam, was getting ready to invade Japan (stopped by the Kamakazi..divine wind), and wanted to see what else was out there to lay his hands on.

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                              Besides that, it was a Nationalist Chinese Cartographer who whimsically put the 9-dash line on a 1946 map he was drawing. That is the strength of the Chinese claim. They had no settlements on the island, and it was Vietnamese, Malay, and Filipino fisherman and traders more than Chinese who plied these waters over the last 3000 years.

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                              As far as the last 40 years... that number was put in place since it allows for the following not to be mentioned...

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                              The Chinese invasion of Tibet in 1949
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                              The Chinese invasion of South Korea in 1950
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                              Armed conflict with Taiwan over Matsu and Quemoy in 1958/59
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                              The Chinese invasion of India in 1962
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                              The Amur River conflict in 1969
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                              The disastrous 1979 invasion of South Vietnam
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                              Now..they are close to conflict with Vietnam, the Philippines and Japan.

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                              Yes... throughout their 65 year history, the Chinese have been a beacon of peace.

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                              CurryBeef albertocane • 6 hours ago

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                              This list is absurd if anybody knows anything. But just one example, China invaded India in 1962?

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                              Sure the Indian has been saying this for a long time, and they still insist that they are just hapless innocent victim against big bad China. In fact at the time of the incident, the West overwhelmingly take the Indian line. After all isn't India a democracy and China a Communist nation and that's the end of the story?

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                              Nowadays a body of works has emerged and challenge this narrative and they give a quite convincing evidence that it is India who is the belligerent. Here are two links for anyone who is interested.

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                              http://gregoryclark.net/redif....

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                              http://asiapacific.anu.edu.au/...

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                              Duncan Tweedy • a day ago

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                              This might be one of the more important articles written this year. This topic has needed a high profile in-depth survey of events for some time now. Howard W. French and The Atlantic are to be commended.

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                              a Filipino...former admiral and national-security adviser...[asked] “Do you think it is natural for a superpower to behave the way China is?”

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                              China's lack of diplomacy and soft power will prove to be its greatest weakness in any global contest of influence.

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                see more

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                  I'm not so sure.                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                   While the US has been tromping around the world littering smart bombs in it's wake, China's been making friends with a lot of people. Just not so much with its immediate neighbors.

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                          Duncan Tweedy PW • a day ago

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                          I certainly wouldn't say that China has "no soft power." Actually, I did write that at first but edited it almost immediately. Much has been written about China's attempts to cultivate soft power. At the risk of posting a TLDR reply, I'm going to quote below some excerpts from an article in Foreign Policy that I think elucidates what I mean when I say China suffers from a "lack of diplomacy and soft power".

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                          Before I do, I just want to remark that it seems to me that much of the cheering for China around the world has not at its core an enthusiasm for Chinese culture or policy, but a desire to see an abatement of the power of the United States. This is in marked contrast to American soft power. I've lived in Turkey, a country with some of the highest disapproval rates of US foreign policy in the world. Yet everywhere I went, people were genuinely delighted to meet an American (even in Istanbul where drunkenly partying Westerners are a common annoyance). During every conversation I had about world events, I was emphatically informed that Turkish people liked Americans, even though they disliked the actions of our government.

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                          That's soft power.

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                          When I met my wife's cousin, a senior engineer tasked with retrofitting Istanbul's buildings for earthquake preparedness, an Herculean effort that should give some clue to his level of intelligence, he was beside himself with glee to sit down and chat with an American. My poor wife could hardly keep up the translation with all the things he wanted to say. One thing in particular stuck with me. He said that a Turk like my wife could go to America and become an American. But the Turks whose great grandparents went to Germany still aren't Germans.

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                          That's also soft power.

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                          People around the world watch Hollywood movies (and complain about them as much as we do, but still watch them--like we do), listen to our pop music, watch our tv shows, and read gossip about our celebrities. There's a disconcertingly huge gap in their understanding of how our society works, but nevertheless they have a direct connection with us through our culture.

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                          Again, soft power.

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                          Despite China's efforts to fund projects in third world countries, there's just no parallel between global attitudes toward China and the examples I cited above.

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                          Ok, here's some more thoughts on soft power from Harvard professor Joseph S. Nye from that FP article:

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                          The soft power of a country rests primarily on three resources: its culture (in places where it is attractive to others), its political values (when it lives up to them at home and abroad), and its foreign policies (when they are seen as legitimate and having moral authority).

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                          Much of America's soft power is produced by civil society -- everything from universities and foundations to Hollywood and pop culture -- not from the government. Sometimes the United States is able to preserve a degree of soft power because of its critical and uncensored civil society even when government actions -- like the invasion of Iraq -- are otherwise undermining it.

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                          Even China's soft-power triumphs, such as the 2008 Beijing Olympics, have quickly turned stale. Not long after the last international athletes had departed, China's domestic crackdown on human rights activists undercut its soft power gains. Again in 2009, the Shanghai Expo was a great success, but it was followed by the jailing of Nobel Peace Laureate Liu Xiaobo and screens were dominated by scenes of an empty chair at the Oslo ceremonies.

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                          China and Russia make the mistake of thinking that government is the main instrument of soft power. In today's world, information is not scarce but attention is, and attention depends on credibility. Government propaganda is rarely credible. The best propaganda is not propaganda. For all the efforts to turn Xinhua and China Central Television into competitors to CNN and the BBC, there is little international audience for brittle propaganda. As the Economist noted about China, "the party has not bought into Mr. Nye's view that soft power springs largely from individuals, the private sector, and civil society. So the government has taken to promoting ancient cultural icons whom it thinks might have global appeal." But soft power doesn't work that way. As Pang Zhongying of Renmin University put it, it highlights "a poverty of thought" among Chinese leaders.

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                          http://www.foreignpolicy.com/a...

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                  Guest Manny Chen • 13 hours ago

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                  I don't know about reading, writing, and speaking, but I'd certainly rather type in English. We don't even have to worry about diacriticals, let alone logosyllabic scripts.

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                  But you raise an excellent point that relates to soft power. English is the global lingua franca of business and science and technology. The historical reasons why this is so are obvious. But having taught English abroad, I also think there are some intrinsic reasons why English accounts for 60% of all foreign language learning in the world.

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                  English has a reputation as one of the more difficult languages in the world to master because of non-phonetic spellings, idioms, homonyms, homophones, homographs, lack of any central authority over usages, and the sheer number of words, including archaic, technical, and scientific terminology, among other reasons.

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                  This depth of vocabulary is not a weakness, it's a strength. It makes English more efficient. When the same block of text is issued in multiple languages, the English version is nearly always the shortest one since there's usually a word that perfectly conveys the meaning, rather than the wordy work-arounds other languages often have to employ.

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                  Despite English's reputation for being tough to master, it's also considered one of the easiest languages to start learning and using at a beginner/intermediate level. Here are some reasons why English is considered one of the easiest languages to learn (but not master):

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                  Verb conjugation: A typical French verb has more than fifty endings that must be learned. A regular English verb has four.

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                  Irregular verbs: It would take less than a page to list all irregular forms of all irregular verbs in English, as compared with sixteen pages for Spanish. All English irregular verbs except “to be” and “to have” are irregular in the same way.

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                  English noun and adjectival forms: Unlike most other European languages, nouns are not more or less arbitrarily divided as being “masculine,” “feminine,” or “neuter.” Adjectives need not change to match noun gender form, nor do they change if a noun is plural.

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                  Written versus spoken forms: Some languages, including French, German, and Greek, among others are very different in their formal written and casual spoken forms. English is not one of these.
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                    see more
